options.title: -u
options.description: Up. If the service is not running, start it. If the service stops, restart it.

options.title: -d
options.description: Down. If the service is running, send it a TERM signal and then a CONT signal. After it stops, do not restart it.

options.title: -o
options.description: Once. If the service is not running, start it. Do not restart it if it stops.

options.title: -p
options.description: Pause. Send the service a STOP signal.

options.title: -c
options.description: Continue. Send the service a CONT signal.

options.title: -h
options.description: Hangup. Send the service a HUP signal.

options.title: -a
options.description: Alarm. Send the service an ALRM signal.

options.title: -i
options.description: Interrupt. Send the service an INT signal.

options.title: -t
options.description: Terminate. Send the service a TERM signal.

options.title: -k
options.description: Kill. Send the service a KILL signal.

options.title: -x
options.description: Exit. supervise will exit as soon as the service is down. If you use this option on a stable system, you're doing something wrong; supervise is designed to run forever.
